data analytics which actually performs streaming sequel in a serverless fashion

perhaps for all of my streams I also want the ability to durably store my

generate an index based on both the time stamps supplied by the original

when it first receives the data and so that now gives you a time indexed
fragment based storage system that can then be exposed to any non latency

list API again the only resource in the system is a stream you put to it and you

case a simple example here might be
motion detection so all the application does is that it it retrieves data from

it sends a trigger to somebody else or or to an interested user it could be
something incredibly more complicated than that for example you might have an

says for this stream I'm going to now start creating my own metadata that is
based on the number of people wearing blue suede shoes and what can do then is
extract that metadata from each each fragment or each frame in the stream and
then create a secondary stream a derived stream if you will and then emit this

these derive streams created that now other applications that don't want to process the entire straw stream coming

ultimately is to make it much easier than it has been before for a developer

about security all data is TLS encrypted on that wire the tokens that we use are
time bound which means after every n minutes this SDK will will request a new
token so that there is never a very large period of time where the same data
has been flowing in the SDK is also customizable it is available as open
source so the data doesn't have to be transported in real time you could have a use case a very
legitimate body one camera use case you don't have network connectivity which means you're going to be spooling that

construct of a content store or a Content buffer that you can then

SDK to retransmit this data you can say I want with the producer SDK
this bit of data so how we built out the SDK is is in this layer cake form if you

the depending on the customer who is performing this integration they'll have
a natural inclination to pick one or the other flavor of this and so the goal
there again has has been to make it easier for different developer
categories and segments to pick the producer SDK that works best for them
while making sure that performance is not compromised because when software is
running on a device we definitely do not have the same degrees of freedom that we
do when we're running software on you know theoretically infinitely scalable cloud okay

and the intent to read data from that stream okay so as I mentioned earlier
you have the ability to set an arbitrary long or small data retention period and

for it to be merited because when you increase your retention period what's going to happen is that we're going to

you decrease retention Peters so you go from 30 days to 14 days something interesting is going to happen
the oldest data that is 30 days old is gonna get trimmed right down to right
down to the 14th day worth of data so decreasing retention period is effectively a data deletion event and

the control plane are tagging related api's you can tag your stream the stream

faces poker table number 5 through number 10 and it's in the high-roller

some of you are probably thinking hey what protocol do you use because that's probably a very popular question the put
media API and its counterpart on the get side use a streaming HTTP we use
streaming HTTP in an interesting way still compliant with the HTTP 1.1 spec
by the way remember when you call that get data endpoint you get a URI that
becomes a sticky end point for that producer and once that connection is opened the producer can stream in
multiple fragments on that open connection which means that you won't pay the overhead of TCP setup and
teardown for every put as you might with a typical restful api call so not only
does that streaming HTTP then allow us to get to a standards compliant way of in a relatively lower latency and lower
overhead for the producer to transmit data what we also do is we care about security which means everything the s in
HTTP for us is going to be TLS encryption on the wire so that's important the third thing is that we
also care about reliability if you sent a piece of media data we want to be very
sure that it made its way to us and we want to be able to tell the producer now
in theory for anybody's dealt with networking you all know that that is a hard problem and we're not saying we
solved it fully but we've tried to make it a little bit better and we do that through a system of bi-directional acts
so when the producer is pushing media for every fragment we receive on the
separate channel we send a received acknowledgment when you decide that you
actually want the data in the stream to be stored we will send a persistent acknowledgement on on that on that
second Channel if you created a stream and you're not currently putting any media into it we
will say hey it's been it's been 30 seconds you asked for you asked for a connection we gave it to you
you haven't put any media I'm gonna send you an idle ACK and be warned that in the next 30 seconds I'm gonna terminate
this connection and you'll have to get the data endpoint again if you want a stream because we're maintaining sticky
endpoints we have to do some level of connection management because these are going to be millions and millions and
millions of devices that are all going to be starting to pump data into the system so that's something unique about
the put media API instantiation and again when you use the producer SDK all

list now this API says that I'm going to assume that you have decided to store
